title: 112_hr828
content: The Act titled "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2012" prohibits individuals with seriously delinquent tax debts from federal employment. The Act "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2012" defines "seriously delinquent tax debt" as an outstanding debt under the Internal Revenue Code with a notice of lien filed, excluding debts being paid timely, under agreement, in collection due process, or with a pending levy. Sec. 7382 of the "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2012" outlines the ineligibility for employment for individuals with seriously delinquent tax debt under the Internal Revenue Code. The term 'employee' refers to individuals in or under an agency, and 'agency' includes Executive agencies, the United States Postal Service, the Postal Regulatory Commission, and employing authorities in the legislative branch. The "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2012" states that individuals with seriously delinquent tax debt are ineligible for federal employment. The head of each agency must ensure that job applicants certify they do not have such debt. The Office of Personnel Management will create necessary regulations for the executive branch. Due process rights will be upheld. The "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2012" prohibits individuals with seriously delinquent tax debt from federal employment. Before a determination is made, individuals have 180 days to prove their debt falls under specific categories. In cases of financial hardship, employees may continue serving if it benefits the United States. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management must report annually to Congress on exemptions granted. The "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2012" prohibits individuals with seriously delinquent tax debt from federal employment. Agencies must review public records to check for tax liens on employees or applicants. If a lien is found, the agency can request tax information from the Treasury to determine if the individual has a seriously delinquent tax debt. The "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2012" requires agencies to give negative consideration to individuals with seriously delinquent tax debt when applying for federal employment. The Secretary of the Treasury provides a standard authorization form for agencies to request tax information. Confidentiality rules prohibit the use of this information for any purpose other than administration. The "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2012" mandates agencies to consider tax debt when hiring. Agencies must use a standard form to request tax information, which must be kept confidential. Non-employees are not allowed access to this information. The "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2012" requires federal agencies to consider tax debt when hiring, with specific provisions regarding ineligibility for employment for individuals with seriously delinquent tax debts. The Act and its amendments will take effect 9 months after enactment.
